Fabrication

Item Creation Process: Crafting · Design · Fabrication · Materials · Production
Design Types: Tools · Clothing and Jewelery · Containers


The first step in fabricating a new object is to select a known design from the character's catalogue of known designs. This catalogue is sorted, first, by type of object (tools, Clothing and Jewelery, and containers). From there, these categories further subdivide until the player has access to the type of object they wish to create.

Once the Design has been selected, it opens the Design dialogue, which displays the object to be created and its stats, a list of the component materials required (with spaces into which they can be dropped), and the character's own inventory.

Once the character has filled the requisite slots in the design they may begin their attempt to fabricate the new object by pressing the Fabricate button which appears.

Unlike many skills, where there is a single check with a threshold that must be overcome, crafting can be an ongoing process in which success is accumulated towards a final result. After the first roll is made the components are formed into a sort of proto-item. Each time a roll is made the roll is subtracted from the target number. That total is added to the item's progress. If the progress equals or exceeds the required amount the item is complete.

Progress

  • Each point of reduction in the difficulty of skill checks to create the item increases the progress needed by 10. This is the only modification that a crafter can make after the design is completed. The most the difficulty can be reduced to in this manner is half the difficulty all other modifications have provided.
  • The base duration of a skill check is determined by the amount of material being included. Each pound of material makes the check take a minute for general work. Fine work with solids, such as with soft materials in jewelery that weighs less than an ounce takes an inordinately long amount of time, taking (1 minus weight) minutes per check. Careful chemical reactions take a number of minutes equal to the highest Malleability of the components.


Failure

  • Solids; If the total ever drops below 0, each check which makes the total progress negative (or more negative) multiplies the absolute value of the "progress" times each component's Fragility to determine the percentage chance that component is ruined at the end of that check.
  • Liquids; If the total ever drops below 0, each check which makes the total progress negative (or more negative) multiplies the absolute value of the "progress" times each component's Malleability minus 100 (this is then divided by 2 for gasses) to determine the percentage chance that component is ruined at the end of that check.

Completion

  • If the final product and the majority of the components are solid, the standard progress required to complete an item is 5000 divided by (the average Malleability of the components minus 10 per component beyond the second, minimum 1).
  • If the final product or the majority of the components are liquid or gas the the progress required is the greater of {5* (the average Reactivity of the components plus the number of components)} or the sum of the Reactivity of the components.
